question: Question_01_(e)
statement:
Let

\[\displaystyle f(x)=kx^2(1-x) \quad \text{if } 0 \leq x \leq 1\] and

\[f(x)=0 \quad \text{if } x < 0 \text{ or } x > 1.\] For what value of
the positive constant $k$ is $f(x)$ a probability density function?
sols:
\textbf{(a)} Using the hint we see that, first of all, \emph{k} needs to
be a positive constant. We can calculate \emph{k} explicitly by
integrating:

\begin{align*}
\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx &= \int_{-\infty}^0 0\,dx + \int_0^1 kx^2(1-x)\,dx + \int_1^\infty 0\,dx \\
&= k \int_0^1 (x^2-x^3)\,dx \\
&= k\left.\left(\frac{x^3}3-\frac{x^4}4\right)\right|_0^1 \\
&= k \left(\frac13 - \frac14\right) \\
&= \frac{k}{12}.
\end{align*}

The only way that this integral has value 1 is when \textbf{\emph{k} =
12}.
hints:
For $f$ to be a probability density function it needs to satisfy two
conditions:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $f$(x) ≥ 0 for all \emph{x},
\item
  $\int_{-\infty}^\infty f(x)\,dx = 1.$
\end{itemize}

Choose \emph{k} such that both conditions are fulfilled.
